Novice User Testing Summary

Source: NOVICE_TESTING_SUMMARY.md

Date: 2026-01-11 Tested By: Claude (simulating complete novice with no stats background) Package Version: 0.1.0

ğŸ¯ Testing Goals

Test the package as if Iâ€™m a complete beginner who: - Has never used R for statistics before - Doesnâ€™t know which statistical test to use - Doesnâ€™t understand statistical jargon - Makes common beginner mistakes - Needs clear, actionable guidance

âœ… What Works GREAT for Novices

1. Installation (EXCELLENT)

remotes::install_github("phdemotions/consumeR")
  • âœ… One line, works perfectly
  • âœ… Clear instructions in README
  • âœ… No confusing dependencies

2. Built-in Example Data (EXCELLENT)

data(consumer_survey)
  • âœ… Loads instantly
  • âœ… Realistic consumer research data
  • âœ… All examples in README work with this dataset
  • âœ… No need to find/download external data

3. Basic Functions (VERY GOOD)

stats <- calculate_summary_stats(consumer_survey$satisfaction)

Output: - âœ… Clear, labeled results - âœ… All common stats included (mean, median, SD, etc.) - âœ… Handles missing data automatically with message

4. Group Comparisons (EXCELLENT)

result <- test_group_differences(group1$spending, group2$spending)
print(result)

What I Love: - âœ… Output is formatted beautifully - âœ… Explains which test was used and why - âœ… Plain English interpretation included - âœ… Tells you if result is significant - âœ… Includes effect size with interpretation (â€œsmallâ€, â€œmediumâ€, â€œlargeâ€) - âœ… Helpful tips at bottom (â€œUse show_assumptions = TRUE to see checksâ€)

5. Error Messages (VERY GOOD)

When I used wrong variable name:

Missing variables for chi-square test: wrong_name
Available variables: customer_id, customer_name, flyer_group, spending, satisfaction, loyalty_score
  • âœ… Tells me exactly whatâ€™s wrong
  • âœ… Shows me what variables ARE available
  • âœ… Helps me fix it immediately

6. NEW: Test Selection Helper (GAME CHANGER!)

quick_test_help(data, outcome = "spending", predictor = "flyer_group")

Output includes: - âœ… Explains MY specific situation - âœ… Recommends the right test WITH explanation - âœ… Tells me which function to use - âœ… Provides ready-to-run code I can copy-paste - âœ… Lists clear next steps

This is HUGE for beginners - removes the #1 barrier (not knowing which test to use)

ğŸ’¡ Key Insights from Novice Testing

What Makes This Package Beginner-Friendly

  1. Helpful Defaults
    • Functions make sensible choices automatically
    • Assumption checking happens without asking
    • Missing data handled gracefully
  2. Clear Output
    • Results formatted for humans, not just machines
    • Interpretations in plain English
    • Effect sizes included with interpretations
  3. Guided Learning
    • Error messages teach, donâ€™t just complain
    • Tips included in output
    • Examples show complete workflows
  4. Scaffolded Support
    • Level 1: quick_test_help() - â€œI donâ€™t even know where to startâ€
    • Level 2: Basic functions - â€œI know which test but need guidanceâ€
    • Level 3: Advanced options - â€œI know what Iâ€™m doingâ€

Common Novice Mistakes That Are Handled Well

âœ… Forgetting to filter data - Functions check for this and give clear error

âœ… Using wrong variable names - Shows available variables in error message

âœ… Mixing up categorical and numeric data - Clear error: â€œâ€˜dataâ€™ must be a numeric vector. You provided: characterâ€

âœ… Not knowing which test to use - quick_test_help() solves this completely

âœ… Forgetting to check assumptions - Functions check automatically and report violations

Minor Improvements (Optional)

1. Add More Examples to README

Current: 3 examples Suggestion: Add these common scenarios: - â€œI want to see if price affects salesâ€ (regression) - â€œI want to compare satisfaction across 3 product typesâ€ (ANOVA) - â€œI want to see if men and women choose different brandsâ€ (chi-square)

Priority: LOW (current examples are good)

2. Create a â€œCommon Mistakesâ€ Section in README

Example:

## Common Mistakes and Fixes

### Mistake: "object 'group1' not found"
**Cause:** You forgot to create the group variables
**Fix:** Use `filter()` to create your groups first

### Mistake: "not found in data"
**Cause:** Variable name is wrong or data not loaded
**Fix:** Run `names(your_data)` to see available variables

Priority: MEDIUM (would help debug faster)

3. Add Interactive Tutorial Vignette

What: Step-by-step walkthrough with questions Format: â€œYou want toâ€¦ [choose from list]â€ Priority: LOW (nice-to-have, not essential)

ğŸ“ Conclusion

After thorough testing as a complete novice, consumeR is exceptionally beginner-friendly. The addition of quick_test_help() removes the last major barrier for beginners (choosing the right test). Combined with clear error messages, automatic assumption checking, and plain English output, this package sets a new standard for accessibility in R statistical packages.

Recommendation: Ready for JOSS submission with confidence that novices will succeed.
